docs.snippet: In addition to double-digit inflation and growing unemployment, Argentina’s worst drought in more than 50 years is magnifying the country’s chances of suffering another economic crisis.
docs.lead_paragraph: In addition to double-digit inflation and growing unemployment, Argentina’s worst drought in more than 50 years is magnifying the country’s chances of suffering another economic crisis.

headline.main: In Parched Argentina, Worries Over Economy Grow
headline.print_headline: In Parched Argentina, Worries Over Economy Grow

docs.snippet: Latin America | Latin America has become more gay-friendly, an article says, as gays have won rights from the region's more globalized, open regimes, and thrive in the more cosmopolitan cities. Chile, Ecuador, Mexico, Brazil, Uruguay and Nicaragua...
docs.lead_paragraph: Latin America | Latin America has become more gay-friendly, an article says, as gays have won rights from the region's more globalized, open regimes, and thrive in the more cosmopolitan cities. Chile, Ecuador, Mexico, Brazil, Uruguay and Nicaragua have all liberalized one way or another since the late 1990's. (On the transgender front, Cuba allows free sex-change operations for qualifying citizens.) Buenos Aires illustrates the trend, as the Times and now the Economist have reported. [Foreign Policy, Economist]
docs.abstract: Latin America | Latin America has become more gay-friendly, an article says, as gays have won rights from the region's more globalized, open regimes, and thrive in the more cosmopolitan cities. Chile, Ecuador, Mexico, Brazil, Uruguay and Nicaragua have all liberalized one way or another since the late 1990's. (On the transgender front, Cuba allows free sex-change operations for qualifying citizens.) Buenos Aires illustrates the trend, as the Times and now the Economist have reported. [Foreign Policy, Economist]

docs.snippet: The idea of investigating Bush administration anti-terror policies has been dismissed by many as politically infeasible. Should Congress do this?
docs.lead_paragraph: A USA Today/Gallup poll in February found that 62 percent of Americans favor a criminal investigation or an independent panel to look into the use of torture, illegal wiretapping, and other alleged abuses of power by the Bush administration. But that idea has been dismissed by many as politically infeasible. And President Obama has said he was "more interested in looking forward than I am in looking backwards."
docs.abstract: The idea of investigating Bush administration anti-terror policies has been dismissed by many as politically infeasible. Should Congress do this?

headline.main: A Truth Commission for the Bush Era?

docs.snippet: PERAZA--Miguel Alcides, figurative painter, born 1951 in Tacuarembo, Uruguay, died February 27, 2009, in New York. Beloved of his wife Grace; Rachel and LoMein; his mother Maria; his son Camelo; his sister Cocona; and his brothers Sergio and Tabarah....
docs.lead_paragraph: PERAZA--Miguel Alcides, figurative painter, born 1951 in Tacuarembo, Uruguay, died February 27, 2009, in New York. Beloved of his wife Grace; Rachel and LoMein; his mother Maria; his son Camelo; his sister Cocona; and his brothers Sergio and Tabarah. We will miss his exuberance, humor, passion, and talent. Memorial service March 28, 1-4pm, AAUW, 111 East 37th St., New York City.

docs.snippet: Latin America | Latin America is going increasingly nuclear in its quest for energy, a scholar writes, for reasons including erratic hydroelectric power and uncertain natural gas supplies from neighboring countries. [Carnegie Endowment]
docs.lead_paragraph: Latin America | Latin America is going increasingly nuclear in its quest for energy, a scholar writes, for reasons including erratic hydroelectric power and uncertain natural gas supplies from neighboring countries. Argentina and Brazil may seek to double or triple existing nuclear capacity. Mexico, Chile and Uruguay also have big plans. "Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez has sought nuclear cooperation from Brazil, France, Iran, and Russia, but few suppliers appear to be biting." For some reason. [Carnegie Endowment]
docs.abstract: Latin America | Latin America is going increasingly nuclear in its quest for energy, a scholar writes, for reasons including erratic hydroelectric power and uncertain natural gas supplies from neighboring countries. [Carnegie Endowment]

docs.snippet: John Turnbull, who runs The Global Game Web site that mixes the world of soccer and culture, offers his Ultimate XI of writers and philosophers.
docs.lead_paragraph: Since 2003 John Turnbull has produced The Global Game, a Web site of world soccer culture. He is coeditor, with Thom Satterlee and Alon Raab, of "The Global Game: Writers on Soccer," published in 2008 by University of Nebraska Press.
docs.abstract: John Turnbull, who runs The Global Game Web site that mixes the world of soccer and culture, offers his Ultimate XI of writers and philosophers.

headline.main: Ultimate XI: Writers Can Play, Too

docs.snippet: The United States men's under-20 national team, with a victory over El Salvador Tuesday night, qualified to play in its seventh straight FIFA U-20 World Cup later this year in Egypt.
docs.lead_paragraph: The United States men's under-20 national team qualified to play in its seventh consecutive FIFA U-20 World Cup on Tuesday by defeating El Salvador, 2-0. The tournament will be played in Egypt this autumn.
docs.abstract: The United States men's under-20 national team, with a victory over El Salvador Tuesday night, qualified to play in its seventh straight FIFA U-20 World Cup later this year in Egypt.

headline.main: Looking Ahead and Back: U.S. in the U-20 World Cup
